paragraphs.name: 07b8
paragraphs.text: I cannot stress this enough. Always design with real content, otherwise you’ll end up with placeholders, lorem ipsums and hamburger menus inside hamburger menus. Content on its own doesn’t make sense, and layouts without content either.

A close relative of tabs deserving its own category. The pattern is adopted on both platforms — iOS and Android — mostly “always visible” and composed of icons with labels. The navigation bar could be hidden/revealed on downward and upward scrolling. One note that I would add, even though Google recommends not using a description for the inactive icons in some cases, I am strongly for using labels. Don’t make navigation a guessing game for users.

A close relative of tabs deserving its own category. The pattern is adopted on both platforms — iOS and Android — mostly “always visible” and composed of icons with labels. The navigation bar could be hidden/revealed on downward and upward scrolling. One note that I would add, even though Google recommends not using a description for the inactive icons in some cases, I am strongly for using labels. Don’t make navigation a guessing game for users.

paragraphs.text: Awesome! Thanks for sharing.

paragraphs.name: 7aaa
paragraphs.text: Interesting article! Hidden nav is always a no no but if there are way too many menu items then scrollable tabs or tabs with more item icon wouldn’t work as well. In such case hamburger is the only option. Although i would encourage to replace hamburger always be it on iOS or android.

paragraphs.name: 3f2a
paragraphs.text: Just to play devil’s advocate… even though the hamburger menu violates several basic design principles, it’s become an established pattern that people recognize. So that counts for something. A lot actually. But that’s not the best defense.

paragraphs.name: f74e
paragraphs.text: I agree. I just implemented the Google specified bottom tabs in our Android app, and immediately realized that they needed persistent labels. Guessing is bad, even if the icon is clear.

virtuals.subtitle: Another approach would be to have visible arrows pointing in the scroll direction.

content.subtitle: Another approach would be to have visible arrows pointing in the scroll direction.

paragraphs.name: 04ff
paragraphs.text: Thanks for the question! People understand tabs but they need a visible cue to see that it is scrollable. The idea is to have the last item only show up partially.
Another approach would be to have visible arrows pointing in the scroll direction.

paragraphs.name: ac4f
paragraphs.text: Great little piece, I cringe when I see huge scrollable drawer menus nowadays. Frankly it’s just lazy design, it means you haven’t put the effort into vetting your personas/user scenarios to establish the hierarchy in navigation and what elements are most important to the user so you can leverage one of (your beautifully stated) alternative paradigms…

paragraphs.name: fa59
paragraphs.text: Great ideas. So how would you handle nested menus (which are often inevitable for bigger company sites etc)?

58330280af2a.title: I 100% agree with this, however I can’t tell you how many times I’ve run into this tension between…

paragraphs.name: e55e
paragraphs.text: I 100% agree with this, however I can’t tell you how many times I’ve run into this tension between content teams wanting to see layout first and design teams wanting to see content first. Someone has to go first. Navigating this potential roadblock is key to successful project mgmt.

9ca0e1d4bad.title: I have a site I created but I also had to give out email addresses to new members of the company.

paragraphs.name: aa9c
paragraphs.text: I have a site I created but I also had to give out email addresses to new members of the company. The best email program seemed to be Thunderbird. It has a hamburger menu in it. Trying to get people to even understand that it was a menu was a challenge. Most people don’t even know what it is. They see it and ignore it. I flatly refuse to ever use one in any web page or app I might create.
